name: 4-bromo-3-fluorobenzenesulfonamide
Reason: The basic unit for the compound is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The sulfonamide group contributes significantly to raising the melting point due to its ability to form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds and polarity (+80 due to dipole interactions and hydrogen bonding). Also, the presence of the bromo group increases the melting point because it increases the molecular weight and polarizability (+30 due to larger atomic size and increased van der Waals forces). However, the fluoro group is a small and highly electronegative substituent that generally increases the melting point by enhancing the rigidity of the molecular structure. The inductive effect of fluorine can slightly increase the melting point due to a greater pull on the electrons (+15 attributed to its electronegativity and contribution to the rigidity of the molecule). These values cumulatively affect the melting point of the compound when added to that of the base benzene molecule.
